Cancel.origin: [when an issuer wrongfully s or otherwise repudiates a credit before presentment of a draft " Uniform Commercial Code "]

1.definition: to destroy the force, validity, or effectiveness of

sub_terms.a: to render (one's will or a provision in one's will) ineffective by purposely making marks through or otherwise marring the text of compare
sub_terms.b: to make (a negotiable instrument) unenforceable esp. by purposely marking through or otherwise marring the words or signature of
sub_terms.c: to mark (a check) to indicate that payment has been made by the bank
sub_terms.d: to withdraw an agreement to honor (a letter of credit) [when an issuer wrongfullyor otherwise repudiates a credit before presentment of a draft ""]

1.note: A check is no longer negotiable once it has been cancelled.

2.definition: to put an end to (a contract)

sub_terms.a: to end (a contract) by discharging the other party from obligations as yet unperformed
sub_terms.b: to end (a contract) in accordance with the provisions of U.C.C. section 2-106 or a similar statute because the other party has breached compare,
sub_terms.c: to put an end to (a lease contract) because of the default of the other party

2.note: Under U.C.C. section 2A-505, a party that cancels because of the other party's default may seek remedies for the default of all or any unperformed part of the lease contract.

3.definition: to terminate (an insurance policy) before the end of policy period usually as allowed by policy provisions
